articles.title: The Thinking Man's Filter
articles.excerpt: Rationality is more than just logical reasoning, it is the disciplined pursuit of truth. It asks fundamental questions: How do we know what we know? What separates justified belief from mere opinion? By what standard can we say something is true?
articles.content:
Rationality is the pursuit of clarity in thought — asking not only what we believe, but why we believe it. At its heart lies the fundamental question: how do we know what we know? This inquiry opens the door to epistemology, the study of knowledge, and to the age-old search for certainty in a world of competing claims.
In exploring rationality, we encounter the theories of truth: the correspondence view, where truth aligns with reality; the coherence view, where truth rests in consistency within a system of beliefs; the pragmatic view, where truth proves itself in practice; and others that wrestle with the tension between appearance and reality. By examining these theories, rationality challenges us to test our assumptions, weigh our reasoning, and refine our understanding of the world.
To be rational is not to dismiss faith, intuition, or tradition, but to hold every claim — whether scientific, philosophical, or theological — to the light of reason, evidence, and reflection. It is an ongoing dialogue between mind and reality, aimed not at final answers but at deeper wisdom.

author.name: Hrafnkell Han
author.bio: A graphic designer and web developer.

seo.title: The Thinking Man's Filter
seo.description: Tackling the question of how we know what we know.

articles.title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to Apologetics
articles.excerpt: Apologetics is the disciplined and rational defense of the Christian faith, engaging both theological reflection and philosophical reasoning. This field seeks not merely to answer objections, but to present a coherent, credible, and intellectually satisfying account of the truths of Christianity. By examining historical evidence, logical arguments, and biblical foundations, apologetics aims to clarify misconceptions, strengthen the faith of believers, and provide thoughtful responses to skeptics and seekers alike.
articles.content: Apologetics is the disciplined and rational defense of the Christian faith, engaging both theological reflection and philosophical reasoning.
